reviewText:
This is a game designer's game. It has a flawless, timeless perfection, right up there with Tetris. This is not a puzzle game, though. It's a tight, twitchy game about perception and nerves, with a bumping soundtrack worth the price of admission by itself.

You are a triangle in the center of the screen, rotating around a hexagon. The only keys required to play the game are left arrow and right arrow. You move at one speed: fast. So the moment and amount of time you press provide all the challenge.

The screen is divided into light and dark sections that radiate from the points of the hexagon. Walls stretch across a section or multiple sections. When you start a game of Super Hexagon, the walls start closing in toward you. If one hits you, game over.

But there's always a way out. You navigate a kind of maze by dodging the walls coming toward you in their multifarious configurations. With practice you can get the timing down and get around a few walls, no problem.

Then the hexagon distorts, and starts throbbing in time to the music, and the screen starts spinning, and flashing, and changing colors, and other tricks that are similarly hard to notice because it's all happening so fast.

Prepare to be punished.

Begin!

TL;DR- Super Hexagon is amazing and well worth the $3. Heck I would even buy it for $10. Just be prepared to cry a little, and don't buy it if you get nauseous looking at flashy things or are prone to seizures.

This game.. Wow. Where should I start? At this point I've only had about 5
hours of playing it, but they have been some of the most frenzied and enjoyable
hours of my life. I've got to say I've never seen a game like this, and I probably
won't again for a long time.

In Super Hexagon, you control a triangle which orbits around a hexagon, centered
on the screen. Around you, there are light and dark sections, made up of the space
between vectors. Within those sections are walls of an outstanding color that
come racing toward the Hexagon. You're essentially within a maze of color. If you
get hit by a wall, it's game over and your score is submitted automatically so that
friends can compete. It may seem like you're trapped, but there is always a way
out, no matter how small the gap or how crazy the maneuver you're required to
pull. Meanwhile, you have a bunch of crazy lights and effects bouncing around
distracting you from the real goal, yet still managing to make the game so much
better. On top of this, the music is classic, and superb.

Super Hexagon will provide you with 6 different levels, ranging from Hexagon ->
Hyper Hexagonest, and from Hard -> Hardestestest. You initially start with the
first three- Hard, Harder, Hardest- but once you last for 60 seconds or longer on
any of them, the levels go into hyper mode, and you also unlock their hyper mode
forms in level select, where you can begin from the 60 second mark at 0 seconds.

The way the levels work is that each level has a set of 5-10 'gauntlets' or patterns
that it cycles through randomly. So for example, Hexagon will start as a few stray
blocks, then it might run its 3x 180 Degree pattern, then its Double Zig-Zag
pattern, and then the hexagon in the center will... You'll see ;) . Each level has
different patterns, though some are shared throughout the game. Hyper modes
contain advanced versions of the patterns used in previous 'normal' levels.

Possibly one of the best things about this game is that it only requires two buttons
to play. These are Left and Right Arrow, or Buttons 1 and 2 on your mouse. You
can also connect a joypad if that's the way you roll. The fact that there is only one
speed for the triangle (fast) makes things difficult. After a while you will adjust
though, and learn to love the way the game works.

Another great feature of Super Hexagon is the fact that once you 'die' from hitting
a wall, you can start over within one second, so even if you do somehow manage
to rage within this beautiful setting, it probably won't last long, because you'll be
off with another try. Other than this, there is an annoying voice when you lose
that tells you it's 'gameover' and also one that says 'again' when you retry, but
these can be disabled by accessing the game's files and moving the sound files.
On top of these things, this game can be booted up and you can be playing any
level within 3 seconds. It loads SO FAST.

Now, do you think this game is worth it? Would you spend
$3 (less than the price of a Big Mac) on this game? I think that you shoul go out and spend your three damn dollars on this amazing game!

90/100.
ENJOY ^_^

reviewText:
Taking Super Hexagon at face value would be missing the point. Its simple graphics and controls hide an incredibly challenging and addictive game that only gets better the longer you play it.

The beat of the music drives the entire experience, sucking you into the epileptic colors and lights of the moving levels. Super Hexagon never goes easy on you or even pretends to want to give you a hand. Its meant for those that love a challenge, that get goosebumps over seeing they beat their hi-scores, and that will spend hours practicing a single level.

If that sounds like you Super Hexagon will not disappoint. Though it began as a mobile game, the move to PC with improved controls only enhances the experience, and I can't imagine playing it any other way. If you are looking for a game that put your reflexes to the test, you've found it.

reviewText:
Two words: Patience Simulator

Let there be no doubt: this game will wreck you. That's also part of the reason why Super Hexagon is so popular, because it is one of the few minimalist games that test your raw skill, and is not afraid to punish you for the smallest of mistakes.

The level design is fairly linear, besides the frequent break-off points that let you choose which semetrical path to follow; these are fairly important in the later levels, where positioning and pre-planning is important for your continued survival. In other words, Super Hexagon will only allow you one or maybe two methods in which to pass by any particular obstacle, and that's it. It's your job to keep up with the ever-changing deluge of shapes rushing to crush your tiny triangle.

The gameplay mechanics are fairly solid, and I haven't had a situation where I can blame my death on the game, but rather on my lack of speed and pre-planning. The only thing I can tell you is that you will die. At lot. That's part of the beauty of Super Hexagon, it's the challenge that forces people like myself to continue the onslaught of shapes, and anything less than victory is an insult; make no mistake, this game is winnable, but you'll have to dedicate large chunks of your time in order to gain the necessary reaction time to complete the levels.

I would estimate that it would take upwards of 20-40 hours for an average player the beat the game, but that's just a guess. Regardless, after all the deaths and failures, final victory has never been sweeter, and you may proudly display your achievements on your Profile page to show to the world just how badass you really are.

So enjoy the game, and make sure to stick with it; if you're not playing this game and learning from it, then it's playing you.

reviewText:
Super Hexagon is more of a virus than a game. Its ludicrously low price during Steam sales makes it a quick fifty cent game for avid users to send to friends (and foes) as a seemingly harmless gift. Most people who receive Super Hexagon even believe it's some sort of joke—after all, it's hard to take such a cheap game seriously at first. But on top of being ridiculously contagious, Super Hexagon tends to leave users in a stunned, almost feverish haze of incredulity. This minimalistic, no-frills action game uses hypnotic trance music and fast-paced action to present players with a heart-palpitating test of mindless reflexes and quick thinking that will keep you coming back to it over and over again.

You play Super Hexagon as one of the simplest characters known to gamers: a triangle. Your triangle acts as a little arrow that circles around the center figure of a hexagon. The goal of Super Hexagon is to stop this arrow from being hit by shapes that come into the center hexagon at a speed that ranges from hectically fast to cataclismically hypersonic. The gameplay is incredibly simplistic, but skill-intensive. The levels are short: it takes only sixty seconds to beat each one, though those sixty seconds must be done without any errors. Completing a level can take hours of retries, each one pitting the player against their best time so far.

Besides its desperately addictive gameplay, one Super Hexagon's most attractive features is, surprisingly enough, the atmosphere of this psychedelically simple action game. Super Hexagon's arena is something like a dance floor: a rhythmically pulsing, spinning, and twisting battleground set to delectably fast-paced trance music from the artist known as Chipzel. Combined with the outlandishly colorful, outstandingly mesmerizing patterns and shapes that make up Super Hexagon's swirling vortex of GAME OVER. BEGIN."

OverviewSuper Hexagon is in my opinion the perfect example of when simplicity does not impact on gameplay. The concept is simple, ridiculous, challenging and to a certain point, addictive. A great, minimalistic rythm game where you control a triangle in its struggle to survive from the evercollapsing environment while nodding your head to some cool electro music.

The Pros: Simple yet Fun - The game's objective is simple. The music keeps it entertaining. The beautiful changing colors make it fun to watch. Even the frustrating deaths make it enjoyable. This is one of those games where you will die. A lot, a lot of times, however you will still try to move on.

Great Music - The game uses groovy, fast paced music that surprisingly won't seem repetitive after listening to it countless times (due to how much you will have to restart the game). I don't even like electro music, but this is amazing. My compliments to the author(s)

Interesting... Art? - The game has a nice rainbow filter and a geometric generating pattern. It blends perfectly with the music. I cannot compliment the graphics that... are not even there, but the minimalist, colorful aproach is something I personally like.
The Cons: Short - The game has 6 levels, or should I say 3, with two difficulty steps each. Although they take a long time to bead, I would have liked to see some more customisability, like a end game feature where you can alter the parameters.

Difficult - I'm not going to sugarcoat it, this game was pretty hard. Look at my playtime. That's how long it took me to beat the last level. While I don't necessarily find it a con, unpatient people will, so heads up before saying: Oh
date: just 6 achievements? I'll do it in an hour!"\nConclusion A great rythm game for cheap

The soundtrack is flawless, it has been described by several experts and a mix between the classiest of jazz and the funkiest of funk. Only way cooler because nobody likes that sort of music.

It has a 5 star safety rating with inbuilt airbags and has been tested in all weather conditions.

It even has super in its name. It you rearrange super and add one letter it spells persue which is a common mispelling of the word pursue. If that doesn't clue you in, nothing will.
You should pursue this game.

reviewText: BEGIN...GAME OVER...BEGIN...GAME OVER...BEGIN... Super Hexagon is what I'd say what happens when videogames go to a rave. It's a very simple game. Make sure your little triangle doesn't touch the flashy lines and shapes coming in at you at a relentless pace. Very simple, very addictive, and put it this way, the end of a level is you lasting >25 seconds, so it's perfect for when you only have a couple of minutes to kill. The music and the pulsing and swirling of the game is hypnotic, I would definitely not recommend it to those who get dizzy or nauseous easily, and never to an epileptic. It's basically 'what if a kaliedoscope was adapted into a game?' I picked this up for a buck when on sale, but 3 bucks is perfectly reasonable. Pick it up and play with it for a few minutes, you won't regret it.

I absolutely love the bright flashing lights, accelerating rotating screen and hexagons flying everywhere. I mean, it is called SUPER hexagon for a reason. I love the loud and booming arcade-style music that intensifies as the lights get brighter and the screen is spinning even faster and faster as you try to make it more than 10 seconds into the game.

Every year I plan on buying some cheap affordable games during steam sales, and recently I have been wanting  to have my dose of epilepsy in a new fashion. So here I was browsing Lord Gaben's miracle and I found supEr hExagon, capital E for emphasis on epilepsy. After many years of trying to find a game to fulfill my nostalgia needs of all my epileptic seizures I had as a kid playing nintendo, I finally found this.

Symptoms may very, like a twitch in your face or random body movements. The longer I play and the better I get, the more twitching I have, but that must mean I just like the game. However, I have yet to turn blue, which is very surprising.

9/10, would be 10 if I turned blue.

reviewText:
I've bought this game when it was on sale for about 30 cents on a flash sale of the 2013 summer sale. When I bought it wasn't thinking anything special, and from the reviews, I thought it was a quick arcade game that was addictive and fun.

It is not a quick arcade game, it is addictive, and probably isn't fun if you're not skilled enough to know what is happening. When you first start you'd probably have a run of 3 seconds. You already feel outraged from the next 5 tries, but can't stop playing because all you need to do to replay is the click of a button.

I beat this game in about 20 hours. I play this game when I want some quick time to pass by, or if I want to beat my high scores, as I am at least in the top 1000 on every level on leaderboards.

Worth the 30 cents, and definitely worth $3 if you're not willing to wait for a sale.

reviewText:
You may have or may not figured from the screenshots but : this is a game where you control a little triangle and dodge whatever is closing in to you , coming from the margins to the centre.

This game has 6 levels (hence hexa) , each being beaten after you survive 60 seconds (hence hexa) , maybe this sounds easy , or if not easy , at least a game which does not last long , well the acual gameplay when you win is 6 minutes , but you will be failing so much in the meantime , wich can drive you crazy , but it still gives you an ache to play it more , rather than just making you ragequit. But it is true you will ragequit sometimes , it's unavoidable.

There is a lady announcer that tells you your current level when you reach it , the level being just a reference to the time in one level (0 seconds=point 10 seconds=line 20 seconds=triangle 30 seconds=square 45 seconds=pentagon 60 seconds=hexagon).She also tells you 'Begin' at the start and 'Game Over' when you fail to avoid the obstacles , (wich trust me , you will hear a lot) and 'Excelent' when you beat your record , you will be happy when you hear this , but most of the times you will die shortly after.

Controls are left and right arrow keys , A and D , left and right mouse buttons , and gamepad.
The soundtrack is amazying , in my opinion , and it fits the game realy well.
The visuals are like you see in the screenshots , also the game is a little bit flashy and fast , and may give some problems to epileptics.

I could detail more , but do you realy need so much reason to buy a 3 euro game that will surely entertain you (but how much is based on your motivation) , and if you have doubts get it at a sale , definately worth it :)

reviewText:
Super Hexagon is a simple, yet fun and addicting arcade, bullet-hell style game that will both infuriate you and greatly elate you. An indie game by Terry Cavanagh that probably didn't take long to make but should keep you coming back for many hours.

What is Super Hexagon?
The game has one simple goal, to move your triangle around the center hexagon to avoid the oncoming trapezoids for as long as possible. This is the only objective in the game, there are other features such as an arcade mode (for tournaments and events) and hyper mode which is a harder variant of the first levels, but that is the core activity.

The game comes with 6 levels (7 if you count the ending sequence), Hexagon, Hexagoner and Hexagonest plus 3 Hyper versions of these 3 too. It has a progressive unlocking system meaning you have to complete Hexagon to unlock Hexagoner and Hyper Hexagon, so if you can't complete the first level you're stuck (if you can't do the first one however it's unlikely you'd be able to complete the others as they are harder).

To complete a level you have to navigate your triangle through the gaps and paths in the onslaught of shapes. Reaching 60 seconds will complete" the level and unlock the next and the relevant hyper stage

reviewText: This game is awesome, but if you get frustrated easily you're going to have a hard time. There are only six levels, but even the first one is very tricky. You must turn your way through the mazes for as long as you can. The goal for each level is 60 seconds, but this can be very tricky. reviewText:
Super Hexagon is an arcade type game where you try to keep your triangle from hitting the walls of spinning hexagons while they come at you very quickly.  This is a review by a disabled gamer (I only play with a mouse).

http://youtu.be/fAtaCmT_YnI

As soon as I opened the game I hit an immediate roadblock.  You begin full screen with your left and right mouse buttons only scrolling the menu.  To actually select anything on the menu, the game says to press space bar.   I later accidentally discovered you can press both mouse buttons simultaneously to act as a space bar. but the game itself never tells you this.  So the first 5 minutes of my experience was spent trying to find someone to come to my PC to press space so I could access options.  Once I had help and could access the options, I could change to windowed mode.  Windowed mode is borderless and worked well with onscreen keyboard.  You can play with your mouse or keyboard only.  There's also an option for joypad.
Gameplay itself can be completely mouse controlled.  Left click to spin board left, right click spin board right.  Clicking needs to be quick to help with precision.  While Fun and adictive, it can also be frustrating. I could only last a few seconds.  The game is difficult for everyone with game modes starting with hard and moving on to harder, hardest & several locked levels.  With that in mind, I also had someone without a disability play and noticed it was still difficult to get far but moves seemed to be more precise.

The game is playable with only a mouse or keyboard.  That is Assuming you can press both mouse buttons at once or have someone who can press space to get it out of full screen, it is mouse only playable.  That being said, if you can't make quick agile clicks, get easily frustrated, or have issues with flashing spinning graphics...  I would avoid this game.

Besides issues you might have with accessibility, the game IS addictive fun, even when you're losing.

reviewText:
Probably the most addicting game I have played in my entire life. Its complexity of maneuvering around the hexagons combined with the trippiness of the maps, makes this one hell of an experience. The difficulty of the game is quite high, so play this game with a mindset that you ARE NOT in fact the master. However, when you crash and burn in the game, it never becomes a rageful experience. You immediately are pulled into the draw of playing just one more round. The rounds are short enough that you don't feel as though you wasted time when you die.

This game is almost a replacement for drugs. While Audiosurf is like smoking weed, Super Hexagon is like being on straight acid.  It fits under Level 3 of the Psychedelic Experience ranking:

Level 3
Very obvious visuals, everything looks curved and warped, patterns and kaleidoscopes seen on walls and faces. Some mild hallucinations such as rivers flowing in wood grain or 'mother of pearl' surfaces. Closed-eye hallucinations become 3-dimensional. There is some confusing of the senses (synesthesia). Time distortions and 'moments of eternity'. Movement at times becomes extremely difficult (too much effort required). Can be achieved with common doses of LSD, psilocybin mushrooms, peyote, ayahuasca, and Super Hexagon.

Welcome to Super Hexagon, the cheapest, but most addicting game you will find in your lifetime.
10/10

reviewText: Super Hexagon is a game by Terry Cavanagh were you play as a small triangle rotating around a hexagon. That's all there is to it and by now you have guessed that this is very minimalistic game. The goal of the game is to survive for as long as possible as walls and shapes approach from all around. Super Hexagon is a difficult twitch based game and you will fail to survive the goal of 60 seconds many many times. Avail ye not however as the game is the modicum of fairness. With practice and memorization you'll learn all the patterns it throws at you and your times will increase. By surviving longer and longer you start to enter into a kind of zone were everything fades away except the game and you eventually get highscores in the high 200s! Since on avarage one round doesn't last more than a minute
date: this game is a great timekiller

reviewText:
This is a great game for those looking for a challenge. It is a simple concept, yet it is well executed, addictive and satisfying to improve at. While it is a difficult game, it is very fair; at no point did I die to something which I felt was 'cheap'. As a result of this, dying didn't particularly frustrate me; instead I kept going to see if I could improve. This was further aided by the fact that the death animation is pretty quick so you can hop back in to the game quickly.
